A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Associative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Center to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Center of a group involves the centralizer of the group, which is the set of all elements that commute with every other element in the group. This definition inherently relies on the operation of the group being well-defined and having certain properties, such as closure and the ability to compose two elements (i.e., multiplication or addition depending on the group). However, the definition of the Center itself does not explicitly require the operation to be associative; it primarily requires that the operation be commutative for elements within the center with respect to all elements in the group.

The Associative Law, on the other hand, states that a law of composition on a set is associative if it satisfies the condition 
$(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c$ in the set. This law is fundamental in the definition of a group itself, as all group operations must be associative. However, the definition of the Center does not directly depend on the Associative Law but rather on the commutativity of certain elements with all others in the group.

Therefore, while the Associative Law is crucial for the overall structure and definition of a group, it is not directly necessary for the definition of the Center of a group. The Center's definition focuses on commutativity within the group, not on the associative property of the group's operation.
